title: "There was blood everywhere" Single mum beaten black and blue by ex-boyfriend slams £200 fine - Mirror Online
text:

A single mum beaten black and blue by her ex-boyfriend has blasted the justice system after he escaped with a £200 fine. 
Dad-of-four David Connelly’s brutal assault left Pauline McSherry's blood on the windows and walls when he repeatedly punched her in the head. 
The battered mum - who was left homeless by the attack - needed stitches and a head scan for the injuries. 
But, to add insult to injury, she's shocked to learn her "controlling" ex Connelly has been hit with a paltry £200 fine by a court . 
Last night, Pauline, 46, told The Daily Record : “In the last year, I have been in a homeless unit and given everything up and all he got was a £200 fine for battering me black and blue, from head to toe.” 
The attack occurred last Easter weekend and Pauline subsequently spent six months living in a homeless unit. 
She explained: “The past year has been a nightmare. 
“It is absolutely disgusting that he got off with a £200 fine. That’s not encouraging men not to hit women. 
“I was not even allowed back in the house for six hours as forensics were in. 
“There was blood splattered everywhere.” The single mum was also left homeless after the incident 
Last month, before Dumbarton Sheriff Court, mechanical welder Connelly, 48, admitted assaulting Pauline. 
The charge stated that on March 27 2016, at their home in Clydebank. near Glasgow, he repeatedly punched his partner on the head and threw her on to a bed all to her injury. 
But when the dad-of-four returned to the dock last week for sentencing, he was hit with a paltry £300 fine. 
Horrified Pauline said: “When he pled guilty I thought, ‘That’s the end of it’. 
“I thought he would get community service.” Pauline pictured with her ex-David Connelly 
Instead, ​Connelly was fined and agreed to pay back the sum by next month. 
Pauline added: “He was pleading financial difficulties but I can assure you his house is bought and paid for, he got a conservatory that was nearly £20,000 done and he has a caravan that is bought and paid for in Glencoe. 
"£200 to him is nothing. 
“My mum and dad are disgusted and my sister said it is absolutely appalling. 
“There was a wee boy in court for a breach of the peace and he got 200 hours’ community service.” 
Pauline started dating widower Connelly in April 2014 but says she ignored warnings from friends that he was “controlling”. Pauline was bruised all over 
The following February, she gave up her flat and moved in with him. 
Eight months later, in October 2015, Pauline claimed Connelly attacked her after a whisky binge but she never phoned the police. 
She said: “I had to take a week off work and lie to my boss. My face was a mess.” 
The following Easter, her parents, who are both in their 60s, came round for dinner on the Saturday night. 
They left at around 12.30am and within an hour Pauline was on the phone to police. Pauline and David had a difficult relationship 
She said: “David had been drinking whisky and just attacked me for no reason at all. 
“It started in the conservatory and continued in the kitchen. 
“I was covered in blood and I didn’t know where it was coming from. 
“I was petrified and I was in shock. 
“I felt sick and dizzy but I knew I had to get up the stairs as I couldn’t get a reception on my phone downstairs to call the police.” 
Pauline was repeatedly punched on the head during the brutal assault. David said they had both been drunk at the time 
As Pauline went upstairs to dial 999, Connelly followed and then sat on their bed with his arms and legs folded. 
She was advised by the operator to stay on the line. Within minutes, two officers were at the door. 
An ambulance was called and Pauline was taken to the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow for a head scan. 
She also required three ​s​titches to a cut above her left eyebrow. 
Connelly was arrested and kept in custody until he appeared in court the following Tuesday. 
Pauline claimed ​his ​two teenage daughters were upstairs at the time of the assault but didn’t react to the commotion – even though a neighbour across the street heard her screams. 
Despite the charge stating she was pushed on to a bed, Pauline maintains the attack happened downstairs. Read More Astonishing moment little girl pulled alive from rubble of air strike in Damascus 
She said: “When I got back into the house, there was specks of blood on the windows of the conservatory and the kitchen and all over the walls. 
“That was me with my hands w​h​en I didn’t know where the blood was coming from.” 
Pauline left the house on Easter Sunday and spent a few days staying with her parents and a friend in Faifley and Clydebank. Neither had enough room for her to stay long-term. 
She added: “I spent six months in a homeless unit. 
“The first house I was offered belonged to his step-daughter so I had to turn it down.” 
Pauline only left the homeless unit in Duntocher last September. 
And the single mum has been so traumatised by the incident she only returned to work this month. Read More 
She added: “I’ve never been back to myself and I still can’t get my head around it.” 
The Record last night spoke to Connelly about the case outside his Clydebank home. 
Speaking of the attack, Connelly said: “We were both drunk, know what I mean? 
"It was just a drunken argument that got out of hand.” 
When it was put to him that he got off lightly for the assault with a £200 fine, Connelly said: “I got off lightly? 
“I had to pay my lawyers. I have been fined. I now have a police record. 
“I never had any convictions for anything.” Like us on Facebook
